Through the diligent efforts of most of the members of the
NAEB Research Cornraittee, and the cooperation of all of the
would-be broadcast researchers who failed to submit applications,
the first task of our committee for 195? was dispatched in record
time. 1 am still not sure why we have failed to get a better
response to our grant®^2in#«id program, Admittedly, $500.00
is small pickings when compared to some of the money floating
around these days but, unlike most such grants in broadcasting,
ours are available for graduate students working under capable
direction, this should certainly be an inducement. Also,
our notices went out much earlier this year than they have
for a mnfeer of years. We tried to place them in the hands
of stations and departments Just after the opening of the
academic year. As Irr Merrill has indicated, if any of you
have ideas for the improvement of this grants program, please
offer them.
Equally important, w© would appreciate ary suggestions which
you have for ways in which you feel our committee might
serve educational broadcasting research. This is not to say
that I think we ought to look for something to do to keep
busy, simply because someone has designated us as a oosisaittee.
(I am certain that none of you needs additional suggestions
far ways to keep busy 1) However, if there is a need which we
might fill, l think that it should be considered by the comittee.
The NAEB currently has two or three proposals before the
Department of Health, Education, and Welfare (under Title VTI
of the HiU-Flliot bill), if one or more of these goes
through, there will certainly be a need for advice and
assistance from laesfcers of the research committee.
I am looking forward to hearing from you. I can be reached

Columbia University.
Samuel L. Becker, Chairman
